Writing an essay can be challenging, especially when you have multiple assignments at the same time. It is hard to manage all the assignments that you receive at the university. But some tricks can make the whole process easier. Here we present some essay writing skills which helps you to get good grades. 1. Before You Start Writing An Essay, It Is Essential To Know What You Want To Say. First of all, pick a topic and plan the essay before you start writing it. Start your first line with the catchy exciting topic. One of the most crucial Essay writing skill is not to use unnecessary words. Academic essay writing is a style that one can learn to write once they know the basics of writing essays. An academic essay should provide a reliable, debatable thesis that is then supported by relevant evidence – whether from other sources or one’s research. Most research guidelines follow a standard set. Memorizing some basic principles for academic essay writing will give you valuable, inspiring papers, even if you are under lack of time. 2. Understand Your Readers While writing your academic essay, always keep your main argument in mind. Try to make your essay audience-friendly. Also, pay full attention to the tone and style you use; Not only to come appropriately for your audience, but also develop flexibility in your writing to communicate with a variety of audiences successfully. 3. Original Content Original content means that the material was never said before i.e., content that was never published online. Everyone knows this is hard, but it’ll be right for you, and it is also a good practice. Do your research and make your content. Do not follow the way of others or don’t try to write from the web. Try to make all the content by yourself without taking help from the internet. 4. Acquire A Solid Understanding Of Basic Grammar, Style, And Punctuation. Without the use of proper grammar, the essay is meaningless cause a little comma or full stop can change the meaning of the whole sentence. So, please be careful with the punctuations. Don’t write too long, complex sentences your sentence shouldn’t leave your reader. They need a high-stop sign with constant shallow breaths. Nor should they gasp long, at the end of any sentence. 5. Use The Right Vocabulary. Find Out Exactly What The Words You Are Using. The most valuable part of the essay is the vocabulary. Vocabulary means the body of words used in a particular language. Don’t repeat the words again and again in the paragraph. Read your essay again and again and make changes where you are repeated words and try to bring the new words in life. Your main argument should be obvious. Don’t leave the topic without explaining it. 6. Last But Not Least Essay Writing Skill; Writing A Conclusion In Conclusion, try not to make too much longer but must include a brief summary of the paper’s main points containing all your primary thoughts. Don’t copy and paste your thesis itself. The conclusion presents the entire essence of the essay. Your conclusion of the paper should remind the reader of the meaning that was contained throughout the essay. 7. You need to be Frankenstein (you know I mean the doctor, right? Not the monster. You can be the monster, but I don’t see how that would help you). Mix some diverse facts together to make something more interesting than the individual parts. Like a man pummeling his ketchup bottle to get the red stuff flowing, I think I tortured my metaphor above. But my point was that you need to bring your information to life. The simplest way to share information concisely is to make a point form list. Brian: Intelligence: Very High Height: 177 cm Weight: also very high … But these numbers don’t really mean anything on their own and if you are writing an essay for a class, all your classmates will have the same numbers to work with. I’ll let you in on a secret: I am overweight. That’s not much of a secret I guess. But the way I would prefer this information to be shared is in describing me as similar to a bear in Autumn. The reader would correctly conclude that I have a lot of body hair, and carrying a lot of fat and might either be cute or ferocious - either one would be cool for others to believe of me. In English class, anyone can say Macbeth was too ambitious. It would be more memorable to compare him to Donald Trump. It might even be cooler to compare Trump to Lade Macbeth as the truly ambitious one. Mike Pence, as Macbeth has no choice but to be dragged along and cannot separate himself from Trump because the way behind is as filled with blood as the way forward. Ah, I’m reaching here. Such comparisons require some creativity but make the essay more interesting and maybe even fun.

In my Creative Writing course at the University, one of the assignments was a Personal Essay. Now this is different than a Personal Essay that you would write as an entrance requirement for a university. The former falls under Creative non-fiction where-as the latter is generally referred to as just a narrative essay. Picturing the Personal Essay: A Visual Guide The difference is how you handle the narrative, because you want to use a plot guide. Do you want to build to a climax? do you want to circle on reflection? etc. This is a good article because it shows a visualized structure of what the plot should feel like to the reader. I struggled long and hard on this. Do I build to a climax with the abuse in my life? That’s generally what led to my suicide attempts. I thought that would be too painful for the teacher to read. So I did a spiral of reflection. The idea came to me when I was ordered to clean the ponds midsummer. There was a scorpion trapped in one pond. I was on a strict deadline, my wife hates interruptions, or excuses, so I, “danced with danger.” Something I learned as a child. I distracted the scorpion with a gloved hand as a target, while speed snatching stones from all around him. I could have killed him, but it wasn’t his fault he got trapped within my task, he shouldn’t pay the price either. So my essay became a reflection, the spiral reflection on other events where I, “danced with danger.” Even how it all started: under a streetlamp with a stuffed raccoon whose throat had been severed and clumsily stitched back together with bandaids as a child would. This is how it is done. You chose a plot profile, a plot style and you frame your narrative around a non-fictional subject. It has all the creative writing narrative methods, plots, characterizations (perhaps), certainly mood and scenes, emotions.

Whether you are writing it for a college application or simply just for fun. There are certain steps to creating a creative essay. Here is the basics. First, you must think of a topic for the story you are about to create. What do you want to write about. Stay creative. Secondly you must identify your main theme. How do you want the reader to feel? Is there a certain point you want to convey in your essay? Third, you must develop a good outline. You want to create all the characters and develop a plot etc. Most importantly, try not to over think it. The main things you want to focus on is how you will draw the attention of the reader and what do you want the message to be. What will the characters do, how will everything fall into place? I'm almost certain you are already aware of the basic principles when it comes to writing, sentence structure, punctuation, paragraph structure, introduction, body & conclusion. Most of all be creative and do not over think it. Hopefully this sums it up for you :)

This depends on many factors. What is the prompt? Is this something for fun? Are you required to have a certain structure? all those things aside, here are a few suggestions to perhaps get you started. What point of view are you writing from? Try to pick a unique character to provide your narration. in my own writing, one of my favorite creative essays was one which I used a mouse as the narrator and described a certain string of events through the mouse's eyes. Start out with a hook! It often intrigues both the writer and the reader if the first sentence starts out with a bang. Such as : "The day struck me as one that should have felt lazy and carefree - with all the sunshine and fluffy clouds - but 46 children were missing". (Not the best example, but what I came up with off the top of my head). You want to keep up a quick pace. Give the reader something to look forward to, and then work your way backwards through the events leading up to the grand finale or big twist.

I think the hardest part of starting any essay is the beginning. Once I get into the flow of things, writing comes much easier to me. So I recommend the upchuck and edit approach. This drove my English major roommate crazy, but I’ve never willingly written a draft. I just dive straight into the meat of the essay and add the fluff later. I also edit as I go, because the path of my essay often changes as I write it. Don't be upset if any of this happens to you. Just follow your brain sparks, and throw all of your ideas down on paper. You can trim things down later. Good luck!

Creativity isn’t a scale where your goal should be to score higher. The purpose of writing is to communicate ideas. If you have something to say, focus on saying it as clearly as possible. If you find yourself at a loss for ideas, why are you writing at all? Ideas don’t come from a vacuum. If you want to have more to say, read more. So whenever you find yourself stuck for something to write about, go read instead. Before long, you’ll have more ideas than time to write about them.

While I don’t spend much of my writing time on essays, the main trick I have almost always used to help make any essay more creative is to be very selective on my word choice and my sentence length. My main recommendation for word choice is to use as precise language as possible. I try to avoid phrases along the lines of “very [blank].” Now, as to sentence length… there’s no problem with using longer sentences. Nor is there a problem with shorter ones. Both surely work. See? The length of the sentence helps give a flow to your writing. Just like how the tide comes a little differently each time it comes in, your sentence length shouldn’t be all the same, as it needs flow. Thanks for reading… Have a wonderful day (every day)! -Zachary Smith
